displayed_text: Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem. Doctor: Just a couple more things So other than the CAT scan you haven’t had any other new scans? Patient: Not for I think about two months, three months, and I had the whole-body scan ordered by I think the thoracic surgeon V___ and that’s been the three lymph nodes on the lungs. Doctor: And that’s all you know from the last time you were here. Patient: Oh no, not since the last time I was here, no, just that one. Doctor: Okay, uh so the test results that we have is your ARV7 test. Dr. G but we had one- Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: and that came back as positive. So some transcripts are negative and some transcripts are positive. But that’s generally considered a positive test, which is a negative thing. Patient: Oh (chuckles) Doctor: And we tried to get your tissues set out for genetic testing, and it wasn’t enough or inadequate for them to run any tests on it. So we don’t have any more data about molecular testing. Dr. G mentions it in his note as well that that’s something that he wants to do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t know where he is with that as to whether he’s going to try a different company or other tissue that he may have. And I don’t know what they sent. Did they send the tissue from your liver or tissue from back when you were first diagnosed? Patient: I don’t know.

Family Member: Okay. Patient: Follow-up question here to Doctor: You could do either way. Family Member: Yeah. And how long are you there when you go get your radiation? Doctor: About a half an hour total. So you do it on your way to work or on the way home. Patient: Okay, so obviously radiation we’re going to do, we’re going to do. In terms of the thought process on the chemo – what’s the – as soon as we’re ready to say yes? Doctor: Just let us know. Patient: Okay. It won’t take long; I just want to absorb everything. Then I get back. Okay. Doctor: Um, R___ do you have any other questions? Family Member 1: Just the sequence of things. The hormone therapy and the chemo therapy and Zytiga. Are they all started at the same time? Doctor: Uh, pretty much, yeah. Um and we could start the hormone shot any time. Patient: I’m scheduled.

Family Member: And we will have a number to call? Doctor: Oh yeah, yep. And I do want to mention as you’re talking about this, he’s also an Iron Man candidate. Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: So in our quest to always get you the most number of trials Mr. W____ that you’re eligible for, (HCP laughs) Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - so that I know and everyone else knows how you’re doing, how you’re feeling – Patient: Um. Doctor: - so that your experience gets you know out there Family Member: Right now as I say… Doctor: Um hmm. Family Member: He to me… Doctor: Um hmm.

Family Member: Okay, good. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If we can get him looked at it’s… Doctor: Well how about any, how is the pain in the neck? Did that flare up? Patient: No. That’s gone. Doctor: That’s been gone too? Patient: Yeah it’s been gone. Doctor: It didn’t come back in between at all? Patient: No. That was a one-week episode. Doctor: Can you move your neck? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Side to side? Does that bring on pain?

Patient: And what is a PSMA? Doctor: That’s literally like a target. It’s like a PSA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s a target on your cells and we try to go after it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That sounds like fun. Patient: Wow. Doctor: And you know in Europe it’s really been done for imaging. Like you really try to oh you do the PSMA scan so you’re trying to find where the cancer is. The struggle you know for us for the drug part is getting enough of a drug level to be able to kill the cell so Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that’s kind of like what this is. So I hope we get a spot but I already told M_____ to stick her foot out. Patient: But you know I mean I really have nothing to complain about because um it’s eleven and a half years since I was diagnosed. Doctor: That’s incredible. Patient: And um all things being considered I guess eleven and half a years ago I didn’t think I’d be here right now.

Family Member 1: And she does yoga. Doctor: I’m very relaxed in here. Oh my gosh. (laughing) Family Member 1: She teaches yoga too Doctor. Doctor: Are you okay? Patient: Yeah, I'm fine. I’m just concerned about that PSA going up. Doctor: Yeah so we gotta start. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, and then, huh, they’ll usually reach out to you about that results. And then, huh, huh, and then I have an appointment if you check out that will coincide with your next shot. Patient: Right. Doctor: Blood work a few days in advance at B___ and a visit with me. So likely that you’re going to be on the abiraterone as you come into that visit. Huh, it’s just an issue of us getting it started. So if you haven’t heard in the next ten days let me know. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, because of the Medicare switch, that may be sort of the only delay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: All righty. Doctor: Good? Family Member: That’s fine. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: What I would like to do, is uh I would like to leave you with this information. Please don’t read it now because I want you to take your time with it. Um it’s it’s pretty intense reading but if if you take it slowly, and then maybe you have people in your family with you, going over it with you. Um and then in in about a week um we will call you back up. I will have my research nurse reach out to you by telephone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And uh see what you think. By then we will have the information from the PSA. And if the PSA is rising again, it it would be my recommendation that at the very least we start the Xtandi. And then addition to that, possibly to consider the clinical trial. But at the very least, I do think Xtandi is going to be a part of your treatment. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And if the PSA has somehow stabilized or dropped on its own, which I don’t anticipate in this case- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But if it has dropped on its own, then I will rewrite your prescription and reauthorize your prescription for the Abiraterone. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, having said all that, I do anticipate that we’re going to be switching gears. Patient: Okay. Sound good to me. Doctor: Are there any other questions you have for me about the clinical trial or about the Xtandi itself?

Patient: Until the third of January or something. Doctor: You could wait until the third of January, or you could -- Patient: Now, if you got - You, you – I grabbed that number out of the air. You can – Doctor: You could try to wait or things like that. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, he could wait. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Because, again, I like to wait a little bit. Patient: After the, uh, hormones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have some data that says says, um, people tolerate the chemo better once, uh, they have a little bit more space between getting the hormones and the chemo together. So Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let your body’s level of testosterone drop. Then, get the chemo, uh - that may be safer on your bone marrow than doing it all at once. Patient: That’s a done deal.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::strongly agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: I – yeah. Whatever. Doctor: I got a great idea! Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s do this! Family Member: I gotta get out. Doctor: Right. (Laughs) Patient: What? Doctor: Let’s get M__ to just talk hard, here’s what gotta do, thinkin’ movin’ forward. Patient: Who is M_? Doctor: M_ S_!!!! You know M_! She’s the research nurse! You’ve talked to her a thousand times already! Patient: Ohhhh. Family Member: She come back every day.

Patient: Yeah, that's better. The pain-- Doctor: Okay. Patient: is, the drops help on that. There's no pain, the throb it’s not there. Doctor: Alright, then now let me see though (whispering) Patient: You were just covering it a little bit there. (pause) Doctor: This one is weeping? Patient: No, that's a, uh, a wart. I covered up. Doctor: Ok, alright. When did that thing--that wasn't there was it, last time? Patient: Well, it’s when cold weather hits it seems like to grow. Doctor: Oh you see, so you get these any way. Patient: Yeah, I go to the Dermanolog, Dermatologist for it. Doctor: Ok.

Patient: Are we giving you a couple alternatives? Doctor: Yeah give me a couple options. Patient: Thursday this week and uh… Family Member: Monday? Patient: No No Tuesday next week. Doctor: Tuesday, good. That works out because then Tuesday I’ll be there too if you have any questions about the consent if anything comes up. So we’ll try for this week Thursday or Tuesday next week. Patient: Yeah. Thursday afternoon. Doctor: Afternoon, sorry. Got it. Family Member: So let’s – okay so that happens. Then what happens next? Doctor: So at that point if everything is looking good we will also be scheduling the biopsy and then the treatment date after that. Patient: And when do I start on the BET? Doctor: So the…

Family Member: Oh, I see. Doctor: I think that’s a little more unusual gene. So. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, whether that’s what it is -- Family Member: It affected pregnancy. So, that’s why it was in our family, but also Doctor: Did they test her children or anything or? Family Member: Uh, no she doesn’t have children. Patient: She doesn’t have children. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: She couldn’t. That’s part of the issue. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: It’s a blood thing, too. So, um. Doctor: It’s, it’s a gene that affects the body’s ability to use folate. (Pause)
